articles.headline: ‘Pure Hell for Victims’ as Stimulus Programs Draw a Flood of Scammers
articles.snippet: Trillions of dollars in stimulus funds have created a rush among criminals to take the money from those who need it the most.
articles.abstract: Trillions of dollars in stimulus funds have created a rush among criminals to take the money from those who need it the most.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government’s stimulus checks were meant to help people exactly like Krystle Phelps of Owasso, Okla.

articles.headline: Luxury Hotel Company Is Biggest Beneficiary of Small-Business Funds
articles.snippet: Ashford Inc. and the real estate investment trusts it oversees have tapped $53 million in Paycheck Protection Program funds via Ritz Carltons and other hotel holdings
articles.abstract: Ashford Inc. and the real estate investment trusts it oversees have tapped $53 million in Paycheck Protection Program funds via Ritz Carltons and other hotel holdings
articles.lead_paragraph: Hotels, luxury resorts and management companies that funnel money back to a single company have secured about $53 million in federal virus aid, the largest known amount to benefit one firm and the latest example of how the government’s small business relief program is also helping big companies.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Tight-Knit Company Towns Reel as Coronavirus Rolls Through
articles.snippet: Cases are leveling off in some coastal cities, but outbreaks are mounting in processing plants and factories in Midwestern towns.
articles.abstract: Cases are leveling off in some coastal cities, but outbreaks are mounting in processing plants and factories in Midwestern towns.
articles.lead_paragraph: As soon as she heard about a cluster of coronavirus cases at the Tyson pork processing plant on the edge of Columbus Junction, Iowa, Cindy Johnston felt a ripple effect through her small community along the Iowa River.

articles.headline: Bezos Takes Back the Wheel at Amazon
articles.snippet: The chief executive, who had distanced himself from day-to-day management, is closely involved in the company’s response to the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The chief executive, who had distanced himself from day-to-day management, is closely involved in the company’s response to the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — At the end of February, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, and his girlfriend, Lauren Sanchez, were in France discussing climate change with President Emmanuel Macron at the Élysée Palace and celebrating atop the Eiffel Tower with the designer Diane von Furstenberg. Days later, paparazzi spotted the couple grabbing dinner at Carbone in New York.

articles.headline: A Coronavirus Death in Early February Was ‘Probably the Tip of an Iceberg’
articles.snippet: The startling discovery that the virus was responsible for a Feb. 6 death in California raises questions about where else it might have been spreading undetected.
articles.abstract: The startling discovery that the virus was responsible for a Feb. 6 death in California raises questions about where else it might have been spreading undetected.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Weeks before there was evidence that the coronavirus was spreading in U.S. communities, Patricia Dowd, a 57-year-old auditor at a Silicon Valley semiconductor manufacturer, developed flulike symptoms and abruptly died in her San Jose kitchen, triggering a search for what had killed her. Flu tests were negative. The coroner was baffled. It appeared that she had suffered a massive heart attack.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Mike Baker, Shawn Hubler and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Health Dept. Official Says Doubts on Hydroxychloroquine Led to His Ouster
articles.snippet: Rick Bright was abruptly dismissed this week as the director of the Department of Health and Human Services’ Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority.
articles.abstract: Rick Bright was abruptly dismissed this week as the director of the Department of Health and Human Services’ Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The official who led the federal agency involved in developing a coronavirus vaccine said on Wednesday that he was removed from his post after he pressed for rigorous vetting of hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malaria drug embraced by President Trump as a coronavirus treatment, and that the administration had put “politics and cronyism ahead of science.”
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Banks Gave Richest Clients ‘Concierge Treatment’ for Pandemic Aid
articles.snippet: Some businesses seeking coronavirus loans got to avoid flaky online portals or backed-up queues. Many other small businesses couldn’t get their loan requests submitted before the money dried up.
articles.abstract: Some businesses seeking coronavirus loans got to avoid flaky online portals or backed-up queues. Many other small businesses couldn’t get their loan requests submitted before the money dried up.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government’s $349 billion aid program for small businesses devastated by the coronavirus pandemic was advertised as first-come, first-served. As many business owners found out, it was anything but.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Jobless Numbers Are ‘Eye-Watering’ but Understate the Crisis
articles.snippet: With 4.4 million added last week, the five-week total passed 26 million. The struggle by states to field claims has hampered economic recovery.
articles.abstract: With 4.4 million added last week, the five-week total passed 26 million. The struggle by states to field claims has hampered economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a month after Washington rushed through an emergency package to aid jobless Americans, millions of laid-off workers have still not been able to apply for those benefits — let alone receive them — because of overwhelmed state unemployment systems.
